Recipe.Description: This is basically French, a quick sauté of beef, potatoes, mushrooms and onions with stock-cream sauce. Being a sauté it is important that you use a heavy, thick-bottomed pan, oil VERY hot (just beginning to smoke) and that ingredients are DRY when they hit the sauté pan. When this dish is done right, each ingredient retains its own character, only the sauce carries the blended flavors which ties it all together (unlike a stew, where everything tastes like everything else).

Prerequisites.Prerequisite: Peel onions: Drop them into boiling water for a minute, then drain. Shave peel from root and tip ends then you can just give 'em a squeeze and pop them out of their skins. Cut a 1/4

Method.Step: Simmer onions in stock with parsley stems until tender, about 20 minutes. Meanwhile...
Sauté potatoes in 1 tbsp butter and a little olive oil with the tarragon until browned and tender. Set aside.
Sauté mushrooms in butter. Add 1/4 of the shallots as the mushrooms begin to brown then transfer to a bowl.
Sauté meat in olive oil and butter, salt and pepper lightly. Cook until just browned, meat should still be rare inside, transfer to bowl with mushrooms.

Remove all but 1 tbsp of fat from the pan, add remainder of shallots and sauté for a minute -just sweat them, deglaze the pan with the wine and add the stock, reserving the onions and discarding the parsley stems. Reduce the sauce to a syrupy consistency, then add the cream.
Add the meat, mushrooms and onions, allow to simmer while you chop the parsley tops.
Return the potatoes to high heat to crisp (add another tbsp of butter if needed), then add to the other ingredients.
Adjust the seasoning, garnish with parsley and serve immediately.
